Dialogue.Stage Direction: July 20th 1966. A truck comes out of the hangar and drives away with the Tardis secured to the flatbed at the back. The Doctor and Jamie try to give chase but soon lose sight of it.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie!
The Tardis!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Next to the hangar is a garage with fuel pumps outside. A man is working at a bench covered in machine parts. A radio is playing music very loudly.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Excuse me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man adjusts his hearing aid.

Dialogue.Line: Ay?
I wonder if you can help us?
My mate likes the wireless turned on at full blast. I have to keep this turned down.
Oh, I see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hall turns the wireless off.

Dialogue.Line: Who's taken the Tardis?
The what?
He means the police telephone box.
He said Tardis or something.
Yes, well, Tardis, that's another name for it.
Oh, foreign, is he?
Me, foreign? You're the one that's foreign. I'm Scottish.
That's right. Tardis is a is a Gaelic word. Jamie, hush.
It's getting further away all the time.
Yes, I know. Well, anyway, it's our property and we've come to collect it.
Oh, you mean the

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man is listening to this in a field next to the airport, through a radio transmitter.

Dialogue.Line: The police box?
Yes!
Yeah. Well, that's gone.
Oh, we know it's gone. That's the whole point. Its ours and somebody's stolen it.
Oh, I don't know about that. I've got a note here somewhere. Yeah, here we are. There. Police Tel Box. Collection 3 o'clock.
Let me see this, please.
Been signed for.
Yes, so I see. J Smith. Doesn't really help us, does it?
Yeah, well, I just do what I'm told. You'd better see the airport Commandant or someone.
Oh, no. I don't think we'd better do that. Jamie, I think we'd better talk to the police.
Of course I, er, I do know the name of the firm what picked it up.
You do?
Yeah, firm name of, er, Leatherman.
Thank you very much. You'll be hearing from us.
Leatherman. Now that's a clue. Just a minute. Now, what street do they? Doctor, wait.(The Doctor drags Jamie outside. Once they are out of sight, Hall talks into his hearing aid.)
Did you get all that?
Every word. We'd better get going. Get your money back at the warehouse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kennedy watches Jamie and the Doctor through binoculars.

Dialogue.Line: We should have followed that clue he gave us.
Perhaps. I think we'd better keep an eye on him.
Why?
Well, didn't you notice his overalls? They were much too small for him, and the top sheet of his clip board was different to all the others. And when we mentioned the police he became friendly.
Aye. Hey, may

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls Jamie out of sight behind some oil drums as Hall walks past. A few moments later, they follow him.

Dialogue.Line: Kennedy to base. Kennedy to base. Do you read me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man in Victorian clothes answers the radio.

Dialogue.Line: Kennedy to base. Do you read?
Yes.
The Doctor and his friend are following Bob Hall.
I knew they would suspect him.
(I'll go on to the warehouse.
Very good, Mister Kennedy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and the Doctor watch Hall drive off in his car.

Dialogue.Line: That's him. There he goes.
Oh, no.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor spots a black cab.

Dialogue.Line: For hire.
Ay?
Follow that car.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a knock at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Yes? PERRY OC]: Perry, sir.
Oh, er, one moment, Mister Perry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Waterfield unbolts the door and lets in a slight man in his early twenties.

Dialogue.Line: It's here.
Good.
Like me to open the shutters, sir? Lovely day outside.
I have a choice between the sun or noise, Mister Perry. I regret shutting out one, but at least I keep out the other.
Yes. (a clock chimes) I say, that's very good. Just come in, eh? Mint condition. Eighteen seventy, is it?
Approximately.
Don't know who your contacts are, sir, but this is marvellous.
Well, Victorian timepieces are my specialty, Mister Perry.
Wish you'd tell me who makes them for you, sir.
But then you would be as wise as I, and that wouldn't do at all, would it?
Whoever makes them, Mister Waterfield, they'd fool an expert. If I didn't know it was impossible, I'd say it was absolutely genuine.
And, er, there was no trouble with the box?
Apparently not. A bit out of our line, isn't it, sir? A battered old police box?
The whims and caprices of our patrons is our line, Mister Perry.
Hmm. Odd though.
Mister Perry, I pay you the sum of 50 guineas per week, do I not?
Pounds, actually, sir. 50 pounds.
Yes. I hope I may be forgiven if I believe that entitles me to demanding less curiosity of you.
Sorry, sir.
It is, I think you will agree, a princely salary.
No complaints on that score. As long as I'm not asked to do anything dicey.
Dicey?
Crooked. Illegal.
Your candour is refreshing, Mister Perry, even if your judgement of character is somewhat questionable.
I didn't mean that
I know perfectly well what you meant. You may rest assured, I shall not ask you to do anything dicey.
No, sir.
I think you are wanted in the shop, Mister Perry.
And the telephone box, sir. What do we do with it?
Do? We do nothing.
Oh, right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Perry leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Nothing except wait.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hall's car is parked in a narrow lane alongside some railway arches with lock up garages.

Dialogue.Line: This is his car. He must be around here somewhere.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is an old abandoned warehouse at the end of the lane.

Dialogue.Line: You sure you weren't followed?
No, course I wasn't. Hey, you haven't told me what this little caper's about yet, Kennedy.
Counted the money yet then, have you?
No, not yet.
Or do you think I made a mistake giving you two fifty instead of seventy five? We thought you might like a little extra.
What for?
You know those two at the hangar?
Yeah?
They're outside. You weren't followed. We'll be ready for them, won't we? That's what the extra's for.
Now listen.
You on one side of the door, me on the other. Right? Straight over their heads. They won't even know what hit them.
Nah, not me, mate.
It's a bit late to argue, isn't it? They're outside.
Now listen, I'm not getting mixed up in no kidnapping, and that's flat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hall turns for the door and Kennedy attacks him.
Jamie hears noises inside.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Well, have you tried the door?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the door.
Hall is lying on the floor.

Dialogue.Line: It's the man in the overalls. It's all right, he's alive.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kennedy leaves unnoticed.

Dialogue.Line: Where's Ken
Ken? Ken who?
Make him tell us where the Tardis is!
No good, he's out cold. See if we can find some water somewhere. Hello, this is something. This really is something.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has found the money.

Dialogue.Line: But why pay him to help steal the Tardis and then knock him on the head?
Why steal the Tardis anyway?
That's what's been bothering me, Jamie, too.
There's no water here. Hey, that looks a lot of money, Doctor.

It's between two and three hundred pounds. Yes, it is a lot, at least for what he had to do. Put on a pair of overalls and just hang around. Come to think of it, why hang around? He was obviously planted. Why not just go off in the lorry?
You've found something else?
I don't know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are cigarettes and a matchbook on the windowsill. The Doctor searches Hall's pockets.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, this man rolled his own cigarettes, so these must belong to somebody else. That's a fair assumption.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A train rumbles past over the arches.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
It's all right. It's only a train.
A what?

Well, it's a train. There are carriages and they go on wheels, on rails, and they're drawn by a steam. Hey, come back!(Hall rushes out of the door and fastens it with a metal bar through the handles.)
Well, give us a hand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: When Jamie stops pushing the door, the bar falls out and the door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Not a sign of him. The only chance we had.
There is this. (the matchbook) The Tricolour. It's a coffee bar, apparently. And that's not all.
Well, what else?
Well, normally people pull out their matches from right to left. These have been torn out from left to right.
What does that mean?
It means we've got to find a coffee bar called The Tricolour, and look for a man called Ken or Kenneth someone, who's left-handed.
Now we've got something to go on.
But it's so little, Jamie. It's too little. He might only have been there once. There's no guarantee he'll ever go there again.
Now, don't give up Doctor. Remember Bruce.
Bruce?
Robert Bruce.
Look, I told you
And they were not aware that you were watching?
No, they were too busy trying to work it all out.
Good.
That Bob Hall was a bit of a problem. I didn't think he'd turn nasty.
You didn't hurt him?
Him? You're joking.
I can assure you that I am not.
He's a lot bigger than me, you know. No, I just battered him one and that was it.
That was what, Kennedy? I must know precisely what has happened. How badly injured was Hall?
Well, a bit dazed, that's all. He just mumbled something then made a run for it when they weren't looking.
And where is he now?
Well, I went round to his place later. There he was coming out the front door, zip bag and everything. He got in a cab and went to Euston.
Were you able to find another hansom and follow him?
Ay?
Did you follow him?
Yeah, yeah. Don't worry about him. He's gone up north.
That disposes of that. Now, this is extremely important. You did leave the matches?
Don't worry about it. The Doctor found the cigarettes and the matches.
And you are certain they were the ones bearing the name of the coffee shop?
Coffee bar.
Yes.
Yes. I told you, it worked like a charm. I never thought it would, but you were quite right. He got onto the name on the matches straight away.
Well, just one last thing, to make quite sure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Waterfield takes two photographs from a deed box.

Dialogue.Line: Now, you are certain that these are the people that you saw?
That's them, yeah. Yeah, definite.
Right. Well, I shall want you to keep out of sight. You'd better stay in the house. And on no account are you to talk to Mister Perry about any of this.
Okay.
Okay? What does that mean?
What? Yes!
Oh, I know my attitude may appear strange to you on occasions, Kennedy.
You want to play the part of the Victorian grandfather, that's all right by me. Must be a pretty good gimmick. You pay me well enough.
It helps to sell to our customers.
Yeah, sure, sure. You've never told me what it is exactly you've got against this Doctor and his friend. Some kind of vendetta or something?
Explanations are not part of our arrangement.
Oh, just wondering.
Imagination is a virtue, but it can become a vice.
Mind me own business. Yeah. I get the message.
Ask Mister Perry to come and see me, will you please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kennedy leaves. Waterfield takes a key from the deed box and goes to the bookcase. He removes a large volume and puts the key into a hidden lock. Kennedy is watching from the hallway as the bookcase slides aside and Waterfield goes into a secret room. He comes out soon after carrying a large brown-paper parcel. He closes the secret door and puts it on the desk.
Kennedy realises Perry is watching him.

Dialogue.Line: He wants to see us.
Oh, thank you. (He knocks four times on the door.)
Who is it?
Perry, sir.
One moment.
You wanted to see me, sir?
Yes. I have an extremely important and delicate task for you to perform.
Oh, yes? I say, you got a new delivery.
Yes.
I didn't see it arrive.
It was delivered last night. I've only just brought it in myself. It is for a new customer.
Oh, yes?
A Doctor Galloway. He's extremely wealthy and an ardent collector.
Of Victoriana, sir?
No less. I do not know the Doctor personally, but we have arranged to meet in the coffee shop, er, bar, nearby.
The Tricolour, sir?

Yes. Unfortunately, I am unable to keep the appointment, so I want you to go instead, Mister Perry. Here is a photograph of Doctor Galloway. This is his assistant and secretary, Mister James McCrimmon. Now, I want you to ask the Doctor to come to the shop tonight. Say at ten o' clock?
Ten o'clock, sir?
Yes. Oh, don't worry, Mister Perry. I shall be attending to him myself. You needn't wait.
Oh, right, sir.
The Doctor is notoriously unpunctual. I fear you may have a long and tedious wait.
I shall find him, sir. Do you want me to go now?
If you please, Mister Perry.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Perry leaves, closing the door.

Kennedy comes out of hiding and listens at the study door. Inside, Waterfield bolts the door and goes inside the secret room again. This area is bright, with a large packing case in one corner. A carved chair faces the far wall where two metal arms extend into the room, about four feet off the floor and eight feet apart. Waterfield adjusts some very un-Victorian equipment and sits in the chair as the machinery hums.

Dialogue.Line: And what are you doing?
I can't make Mister Waterfield hear me. I knocked.
He's busy.
Okay, I'll try later.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: 'Nobody Knows the Trouble I've Seen' by the Seekers is playing on the jukebox.

Dialogue.Line: Don't look so depressed, Doctor.
If only we knew what he looked like, Jamie.
We'll ask one of the lasses in a moment, when things get quieter.
We've got to untangle this, you know.
It's all quite obvious to me.
Oh?
They're just robbers. Thieves, you understand.
No, no. There's more to it than that. Why leave that man in the hangar to give us a clue?
Which we haven't followed up, you know. Leatherman.
There is no delivery firm of that name. Not in the London area, anyway. I checked in the phone book.
But surely there's more places than London.
Maybe.
Do you think this is some sort of a trap, Doctor?
Yes. If only we knew who our enemies are.
Not the Chameleons again!
No, something else. I can feel them, closing in all around us.
I've done everything that you've asked of me. Isn't that enough? Now you must tell me the truth. Do you hear? The truth!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kennedy is listening at the study door.

Dialogue.Line: But you must tell me. I demand! I'm talking to you! Come back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Waterfield comes out of the secret room, sweaty and tired, and locks it up. Then he lies down on his couch. With nothing more heard, Kennedy leaves.

The Doctor is building a tower of sugar cubes as Jamie returns from the counter, evading the attentions of a young lady in a mini-kilt. The jukebox has moved onto Hold Tight by Dave Dee, Dozy, Beaky, Mitch and Titch.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, if only the Laird could see that! Why do I get all the difficult tasks, Doctor?
Because you're so much better at them than I am, Jamie. Now, what did you find out?
None of the lasses here can remember anybody called Ken or Kenneth.
Oh, dear.
Aye. But, they do have a different lot on duty in the evening. Now, maybe they'll know.
Jamie, I'm being stared at. Is there something wrong with me?
You mean up here, Doctor?
Is my hair in disarray?
Well, no more than usual.
Do I look strange or bizarre?
Aye. Well maybe I'm just used to you.
That's some comfort. Look out, he's coming over.
I beg your pardon.
Not at all.
It is Doctor Galloway, isn't it?
Dr. Galloway?
and Mister McCrimmon.
Aye, I'm Jamie McCrimmon.
My card.
Yes, er, Mister Perry?
Mister Waterfield's frightfully sorry, but he can't meet you as arranged.
Oh. Oh, dear. What a pity.
But he said if you'd care to come to the shop at about ten tonight, he'll see to you personally.
At about 10. Oh, yes. We'll be there.
Right-ho.
Right.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Perry leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Edward Waterfield. Genuine Victoriana.
It can't be a mistake. Even though he got your name wrong, he knew mine.
I wonder if Mister Kenneth has found us.
Ay?
K. Perry, Esquire. Yes, I think we'll go and see Mister Edward Waterfield.
And he definitely said he would be here?
Yes, sir.
Thank you. You have done excellently, Mister Perry. Good night.
See you in the morning, sir?
Yes. Yes, in the morning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Waterfield follows Perry out, locking the study behind him. He hears the front door shut.

Dialogue.Line: Kennedy. Kennedy?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kennedy appears.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor is coming here tonight. I shall want you to help me. And you had better put some warm clothes on. Dark things.
All right. You'd better make sure that police box is well covered-up, in case the Doctor starts snooping about.

Yes.(Waterfield leaves. Kennedy looks at his watch then the study door, then takes a lock-pick from his back pocket and breaks into the study before going back to the hall for his jacket and briefcase. In the study, he searches the desk drawers. Kennedy tries to force the deed box but fails. Searching for a hidden safe, he accidentally opens the door to the secret room.)

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kennedy tries to run for it, but the Dalek fires, killing him. Then it backs into the transmat device and disappears again.
The Doctor silences the door bell as they enter.

Dialogue.Line: I don't know what you're being so cautious about.
Shh!
They left the door open for us, didn't they?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A multitude of clocks chime.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, it's half-past the nine o'clock.
Yes, I know.
But they made the appointment for ten. Why have we come early?
The early bird catches the worm, Jamie. Now do be quiet, there's a good chap. And for heaven's sake, don't knock into anything.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor brushes past a statuette on a pedestal and Jamie catches it before it falls.

Dialogue.Line: Shh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie looks at the statuette.

Dialogue.Line: Any good, this?
It's interesting. In fact, Jamie, it's quite remarkable.
Hey, Doctor, you know you told me outside it said Genuine Victorian Antiques? Well, all the stuff in here's brand new.
Hmm, you've noticed that.
Of course I did. The man's a rogue.
Yes, so it seems. Except
Except what?
Except that all these things are not reproductions. They're all genuine.
Now, that's ridiculous.
Here, look at this. To one deed box, four guineas. This is a bill from William Dearing and Son, 1866.
Then it's a forgery.
Yes. If you were going to make a forgery, wouldn't you try to dirty it up a bit? Yellow the edges, crinkle it up? This is brand new.
I've got an idea.
What?
All the stuff in here is genuine.
Yes.
But brand new.
Well done.
Well, that is impossible, unless Waterfield could have invented a time machine like the Tardis, Doctor, and he's bringing all this stuff back from Victorian times.
But it's not very likely, is it? The only way to find out is to ask Waterfield.
Kennedy!
What happened?
The human discovered our communications system.
And you murdered him?
He would have betrayed us.
You don't have to kill!
Silence!
I won't be silent! What are you dragging me into? You've destroyed a human life. Don't you understand that?
That is of no consequence.
No consequence?
There is only one form of life that matters. Dalek life. Obey your orders, Waterfield.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek dematerializes.

Dialogue.Line: No, wait, wait! What am I to do with the body? I can't, I can't go on with this.
I'm sure I heard somebody shouting. Jamie, we've got to get in there.
What about the wire?
It's too pliable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hear somebody coming, and hide. The shop door opens, ringing the bell. Waterfield checks the servant's indicator. The Doctor sneaks up behind the newcomer.

Dialogue.Line: Boo!
Oh! What are you doing here?
You made the appointment.
For ten o'clock.
Yes, well, we thought we'd be early. What are you doing here?
I work here.
Then what are you creeping about for?
Er.
Aye.
Yes, I think you've got some explaining to do, Mister Kenneth Perry.
My name isn't Kenneth, it's Keith. Now look, I don't understand this.
So, it's Keith. Do you know a man called Bob Hall?
Well, he's a man Mister Waterfield employs.
Well, he keeps some very rough company, including a man called Ken.
Ken. Kennedy?
What? What do you know about Kennedy?
Oh, wait a minute. This is all too quick for me. Look, I'll answer your questions, if you'll answer mine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Waterfield takes the photograph of the Doctor into the secret room, takes a box out of a valise and tears the photograph in half. He then puts half the picture in the box to make it look as if it was torn and trapped as the lid was shut.

Dialogue.Line: This old police box was for a collector of curios.
But it belongs to me.
But why is it so important to you?
Because, because of what's inside it and because it happens to be my property.
Look, where is it?
At the back.
Well, is there another way through? This door is locked.
We might be able to get over the yard gates. You see, this door has an electric lock on it.
You're going to show me where this yard of yours is.
I say, if it's a police box, shouldn't we get the police?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
That's Kennedy!
He's dead.
What are you doing?
Getting the police. What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a buzzing sound on the line. Perry puts the telephone down.

Dialogue.Line: I don't think you ought to touch anything. I'll be as quick as I can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Perry leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Should we have let him go?
No, he's doing the right thing.
But the Tardis?
Yes, well, we'll have to find it before he comes back. Now I wonder what this telephone interference is.
Looks as if Waterfield's cleared out.
Why make an appointment to see us at ten?
Well, obviously, he didn't know he was going to have a fight with Kennedy. Och, come on Doctor, lets find the Tardis and go.
Yes, yes, the Tardis. Now, how did he die? His limbs are stiff, his hands clenched. Look, he died in horrible agony. Look at his face. Hello?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is half a photograph in Kennedy's hand.

Dialogue.Line: What? It's your picture!
Yes. Now, he fell like that, with his arm stretched out. Jamie, go out into the hall and measure the length of it up to the door here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor paces out the study.

Dialogue.Line: Fourteen, fifteen.
It's only five from the door to the wall. There must be another room behind here.
Hey Doctor, there's a keyhole.
Yes, you're right. Now, Waterfield will have the key. We'd better find something to prise it open with.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door opens.
Waterfield watches from the study.

Dialogue.Line: Well, look at this. That's where your telephone interference is coming from. Oh, yes, this is interesting.
Hey, the other half of your picture.
Yes. Don't open that!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Too late. A gas makes them collapse. Waterfield enters with a handkerchief over his mouth and closes the box. He stands in the transmat with the Doctor and Jamie.
Perry enters with a policeman.

Dialogue.Line: This way, along here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile Waterfield, the Doctor and Jamie dematerialise, along with the entire transmat apparatus.

Dialogue.Line: Here we are. That's funny. There were a couple of other gentlemen here. They seem to have disappeared.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Birdsong can be heard through the open doors. The Doctor and Jamie are tucked up on chairs, with blankets over them. The Doctor wakes, groaning, and there is a knock at the door. A maid servant enters with a tray.

Dialogue.Line: Hello sir. Are you feeling better? Oh, you did have a party last night, didn't you sir? The master sent this in for you.
The master? Mister Waterfield?
Oh, no, sir, Mister Maxtible. Mister Waterfield came back from abroad last night, sir, with you and the young gentleman. Don't you remember?
Not very well, no. Ooh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mollie pours a glass of liquid for the Doctor, which does him a power of good.

Dialogue.Line: I'd best not wake him.
What's your name?
Mollie Dawson, sir.
This works remarkably quickly, doesn't it?
Am I to pour some more?
No. No thank you, Mollie. But, you can tell me what the date is.
The date?
Yes, I'm feeling very much better, but I don't seem to be able to remember the date and where I am.

Mollie, that will do. The answers you require, sir, might come better from me. My name is Theodore Maxtible and I am the owner of this house. Pray, don't get up. I have the greatest sympathy for your condition, since I was the cause of it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Underneath those whiskers is the wonderful  Marius Goring.

Dialogue.Line: And this is Mister Edward Waterfield, I presume. You don't keep your appointments, do you?
There were circumstances.
Yes, indeed there were.
Please, please, Doctor. First things first. You asked what date it was and where you were.
Yes. Well?
You're in my house, some miles from Canterbury. The date is June the 2nd, eighteen hundred and sixty six.
And just what do you think you're up to? You steal my property, you spirit Jamie and me a hundred years back in time and you murder a man along the way.
We had nothing to do with the death of that man.
I don't believe you!
You will believe, Doctor. We are all of us the victims of a higher power. A power more evil and more terrible than the human brain can imagine.
Power? Victims? What do you mean?
They've taken my daughter, Victoria.
Who are they?
You will not be kept in suspense very much longer, Doctor. Pray, come with us and we will show you how it all began.
Doctor, do whatever it is they ask, I beg of you. My daughter's life is in your hands.
I will listen, I promise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Waterfield is looking at a portrait over the fireplace.

Dialogue.Line: Is that your daughter?
No, sir. That is a painting of my wife as a young girl. She is dead now, rest her soul, but Victoria is the image of her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria is feeding the birds through the bars at her window when the door opens.

Dialogue.Line: You have not eaten. You will eat. That is an order. Answer!
Yes.
You will not feed the flying pests outside. Answer!
Yes.
Move to the machine. Move!

Dialogue.Character: (Victoria steps between two columns of lights, and there is a brain-splitting whine. VICTORIA
Dialogue.Line: No, no.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The numbers on the wall read 111-968, 2113-4, 7582-1

Dialogue.Line: Move. Move! The weight of your body has fallen by seventeen ounces.
What do you expect? What do you expect? For pity's sake, let me go! DALEK: Speak when you are told to speak! More food will come. Eat it, or you will be fed by force!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lots of bubbling retorts and rubber tubing.

Dialogue.Line: Here we are, Doctor. This is hallowed ground. Here we shall not be disturbed by the servants.
Oh, yes, yes, very impressive. And now perhaps you'll explain what all this is about?
Patience, my dear sir, a little longer.
Patience? You don't seem to understand what's happened. A man has been murdered! You behave as though we're going on Sunday school outing.
Neither Whitefield nor I were responsible for his death. A cigar?
Why have you brought us here? Who are these enemies of yours, these ones you say control you?
Brilliant minds, Doctor.
They are monsters.
Oh, I admit, Waterfield, they have behaved callously.
Inhuman monsters!
Inhuman?
Creations of the devil!
Let me explain.
Please do.

I have always been fascinated by the concept of travelling through time. Waterfield here is an expert in certain technical matters and I have the money to indulge my whims. Everything you see about you here was constructed by us two.
To try to find a way of exploring time?
Yes. Now this is my theory. A mirror reflects an image, does it not?
Yes.

So, you may be standing there, and yet appear to be standing fifty feet away. Well, following the new investigations twelve years ago by J Clark Maxwell into electromagnetism and the experiments by Faraday into static electricity.
Static?
Correct. Waterfield and I first attempted to refine the image in the mirror, and then to project it. In here, Doctor, are one hundred and forty four separate mirrors.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are behind a pair of gothic pointed doors.

Dialogue.Line: And each is of polished metal. Each is subjected to electric charges, all positive.
Like repels like in electricity, Doctor, and so next, Waterfield and I attempted to repel the image in the mirrors, wherever we directed.
You mentioned static electricity.
That was our last experiment. Negative and positive electricity had failed, so we tried static. If only we could have known the powers we were going to unleash.
Powers?
In the middle of our final test with static, creatures burst out of the cabinet, invaded the house, took away my daughter.
Oh, my dear fellow. My dear, dear fellow. But we shall win through now that the Doctor is here.
These creatures?

We had opened the way for them with our experiments. They forced me into the horror of time travel, Doctor. They ordered me to steal a box belonging to you and thus lure you into a trap and transport you here, together with your colleague Mister McCrimmon.
They knew about me, these creatures.
They gave us likenesses.
What could I do? They said my daughter would die.
What are they called, these creatures?
Doctor! Now do you understand?
Oh, yes. Perfectly.
Move back! Our plan has worked. We shall triumph! You will obey! You will obey!
Obey? Obey? What do you want?
We have your time ship. We will destroy it unless you help us with an experiment.
What experiment?
You will help the Daleks test another human being.
What sort of test?
Do not question!
I will not be your slave!
Doctor, I beg you.
No harm will come to you if you agree. Where is your companion?
Jamie?
He is in the house. I have done everything you asked me to.
Why do you ask about Jamie? DALEK: He is the human being who is to be tested.
What do you mean? Tested how?
Silence! You will reveal nothing to your companion. Obey the Daleks! You are in our power!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek goes into the mirrored room.

Dialogue.Line: What have you done with your infernal meddling? What is this test? Do either of you know?
No.
I believe I do. They, I mean the Daleks, tell me they have always been defeated by human beings.
In the long run, yes.
Possibly because of some factor, possessed by human beings
Possibly.
That is absent in Daleks.
Possibly.
Perhaps they want to find out what it is and transplant it into their race.
But if they do that, allied with their own alien intelligence, they'll be invincible! Maxtible, you should've
Oh, my dear fellow. I am merely surmising. I know nothing definite. But, besides, what could we have done? Even if I had known for certain, the fact was, nay is, they hold your daughter, Victoria.
And now they've got Jamie.
Oh, I'm sorry, sir. I didn't mean to wake you. There.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie clutches his head.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's not funny. Oh.
The master left this for you to drink, sir. This'll clear away the cobwebs. Here you are, sir.
Where's the Doctor? Oh.
He's with the master and Mister Waterfield, sir.
Waterfield?
Mollie? What are you doing here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Welcome Brigit Forsyth, everyone.

Dialogue.Line: Just seeing to the young gentleman, miss.
Go and bring some tea. Well, go along.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mollie leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Please, Mister McCrimmon.
You know my name?
My father told me that you and your friend arrived last night with Mister Waterfield.
Your father? I'm sorry but I seem to have great difficulty in remembering anything.
He owns this house. I'm his daughter, Ruth Maxtible.
How do you do? Have you seen the Doctor this morning?
He's talking with my father. He'll be along presently. Do you have everything you need?
I don't know what this stuff is, but it seems to work all right.
Mollie shall bring you some tea in a minute.
I'm obliged to you. Er, Miss Maxtible?
Yes?
Could you tell me who that is in the portrait?
That's a portrait of Mister Waterfield's late wife.
She was very lovely.
Yes, and his daughter looks just like her. You're quite comfortable?
Yes. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ruth leaves. Jamie starts to search a writing bureau as a ruffian enters through the French windows and hides behind a curtain. He is played by Windsor Davies.

Dialogue.Line: Eighteen sixty six. So that's what Waterfield's done.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie looks around the room then picks up his blanket and moves his chair to face the couch. Toby the ruffian hits him over the back of the head then leaves when there is a knocking on the door.

Dialogue.Line: Here we are sir. I've been as quick as I could. Shall I pour for you? Poor young gentleman. They shouldn't have given you so much to drink.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Toby returns and grabs Mollie from behind with his hand over her mouth.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I do ask you to consider.
I have made up my mind.
But they ordered you not to tell your friend McCrimmon anything.
Do you think I'm going to allow Jamie to run into danger without telling him anything? No, I will not.
But suppose he refuses to do what they want?
We shall see.
He's still asleep. The gas in that box of yours was pretty potent.
It was Maxtible's invention.
Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But it is not Jamie under the blanket.

Dialogue.Line: Mollie!
Order the Doctor to begin the test.
But I must first explain to him what he has to do.
Go now. Obey the Daleks!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is examining marks on the floor with his magnifying glass.

Dialogue.Line: But your friend is vital to the plan of these Daleks. Absolutely essential.
So it seems. So who can have kidnapped him?

Oh, why won't you understand? The threats they make are not idle ones. Kennedy was murdered. Without your friend, our only hope is gone unless, unless you know something. You seem to be well acquainted with the creatures.
Everything you say, Waterfield, is true. If we cannot find Jamie, the Daleks will take pleasure in killing everyone in sight, and their greatest pleasure will be in killing me.
Mollie, Mollie. Mister McCrimmon has been kidnapped. It means the end of us unless we can find him quickly.
Straw.
I beg your pardon?
A piece of straw.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It was stuck in the mud by the French windows.

Dialogue.Line: Had a cosy little sleep, young swell?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie pushes him away.

Dialogue.Line: Lively, is it? Maybe you'd like to sleep again? I've got Mister Nod here. He'll have you snoring as good as ever.
What do you want?
I'm to be well paid. Have no fear of that.
Aye, and for what? I don't know you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another man enters. He is very well-spoken.

Dialogue.Line: This your man, sir?
Toby! What in Hades have you done?
Why, I brought him from the house, like you said.
I said nothing of the kind.
Well, you did, sir. Honest you did. A guinea you promised me, and I done what you said. You don't get out of paying.

Be careful how you speak to me, Toby. There's your money. Get out!(Toby picks up the coin and leaves. Terrall steps towards Jamie then stops. He appears to be in great pain. Then he is suddenly normal again.)
Where's Toby?
You just sent him about his business. Look, what's the matter? Are you all right?
Where's Victoria Waterfield?
I don't know.
Yes, you do.
I tell you, I don't even know her.
You're in the house, a friend of Maxtible's. You must know.
No, listen, I'm telling

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall grimaces in pain again, then recovers.

Dialogue.Line: Ah ha, I must apologise for that villain Toby. He was telling lies, of course. I shall escort you to the house.
You just asked me about Victoria Waterfield.
She's in Paris. I'm afraid I haven't introduced myself. Arthur Terrall.
No, never mind about that. Did you or did you not, ask that man to knock me on the head and bring me in here?
I, oh certainly not!
Oh. Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The DOCTOR enters.

Dialogue.Line: Oh. I see you're in good hands now. I won't detain you any further. Good day, Doctor.
Oh, good day to you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He's mad. Stark, staring mad.
Yes, I know. I was listening. Let's have a look at that head of yours.
Och, it's all right.
Come along.

One minute he says this, the next minute he says that. Can you make it out, Doctor? I'm knocked on the head and I'm brought in here. Then that man Terrall enters and denies having ordered the other man to do it. Well, then he changes, and he starts asking about Victoria Waterfield and in the next breath, he tells me she's in Paris.
I know what's happened to Victoria.
What has?
She's a prisoner of the Daleks.
Hurry!
Why am I being moved? Are you taking me back to my father?
No. You are being moved. Pick up your cover. Follow. Do not be afraid. You are not to be exterminated.
Do not delay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria stops at a window to look outside at the gardens.

Dialogue.Line: Move.
You warned him, told him about the Daleks?
Yes, of course I did!
But you were expressly told
Oh, fiddlesticks! Bosh! Jamie will cooperate. You may be certain of that.
Are you sure?
Yes, perfectly sure. Jamie will do everything he is asked to do. Now come along, we must go and find Maxtible.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie has overheard this, and is worried.
Maxtible is working when a Dalek comes out of the mirrored room.

Dialogue.Line: The female human being has been moved.
Everything is prepared.
The testing equipment is ready?
I think you will be pleased with the man I have had specially brought from London. He works in my house.
Show me.

You will understand that he is rather simple. He is quite dumb, but that has its advantages for us. His mind is, how shall I say, undeveloped. He will not understand you, the Daleks. I mean, he will be terrified of you.
Show me.
Oh, I beg your pardon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek backs into the mirrored room to watch. Maxtible calls into the corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Kemel!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A giant man appears, in traditional Turkish dress.

Dialogue.Line: Will you come with me? I want you to stand here. No, no, no, no, no, face the cabinet. Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible gives Kemel a thick iron bar.

Dialogue.Line: Now, bend that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel tests the bar against his leg, then removes his waistcoat and shirt and starts to bend the bar against the back of his neck. Then he removes it and finishes the job with upper body strength alone.

Dialogue.Line: Excellent, Kemel, excellent. Now, you'll help me with these stools.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible puts two stools a short distance apart and puts a thick plank of wood across the top.

Dialogue.Line: There. Now, Kemel, one blow. Break the plank!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He does so with one fist.

Dialogue.Line: Very good, Kemel. I'm very pleased with you. Now you can put on your jacket. Come over here. Now, I want you to listen carefully. You see this man?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He shows Kemel a photograph of Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Now, I'm going to take you to a place that I want you to guard. This young man will try and get past you and you are not to let him. Do you understand? Oh, he's an evil villain, Kemel. A cutthroat who would gladly murder us all in our beds if he could. You will remember this man? Right. Well, you come with me and I will direct you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible and Kemel leave, and the Dalek comes out to look closely at the bent iron bar.

Dialogue.Line: You wait here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible takes a candle and matches from an upper shelf.

Dialogue.Line: This is the entrance to the south wing of my house, and through here will pass the man I showed you in the picture. The door itself is an obstacle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible presses a hidden switch and a door at the back of the alcove opens.

Dialogue.Line: No, no, wait!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible stops Kemel getting speared by metal spikes that thud down across the entrance. He presses a second switch and the spikes retract.

Dialogue.Line: Now, if he gets through here, you will deal with him. Go now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel moves down the corridor. Maxtible closes the alcove door and blows out the candle.

Dialogue.Line: We do not trust you.
Then we're quits, aren't we?
But we have your time machine.
Yes.
So, you will obey us.
They want the human factor, is that right?
Yes, that is what they want.
Very complex. And you want to introduce this human factor into the race of Daleks?
Yes, the conquest of humanity has eluded us. The Daleks must know why.
Well why choose Jamie for this test?
His travelling with you makes him unique.
But why him, why not me?
Request denied.
Why?
You have travelled too much through time. You are more than human.
I see. What is this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three large packing cases beside the workbench. Maxtible enters.

Dialogue.Line: They have been brought from the Dalek planet.
Skaro?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible removes the lid from one case. Inside is a Dalek without its metal casing.

Dialogue.Line: their life force is dormant. Before it is activated, we want
You want the human factor introduced. I see.
You will obey us.
I will make up my own mind!
Do not antagonise them, Doctor. They will destroy your time machine.
And if I agree, it means the creation of a race of super Daleks. My Tardis. I have no choice, do I. Very well, I agree.
The human being with you must not be aware of the trial.
I quite understand.
Make him begin the test.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek goes into the mirrored room.

Dialogue.Line: What must Jamie do?
Attempt to rescue Waterfield's daughter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is waiting when Mollie shows in Ruth and Terrall.

Dialogue.Line: There we are, sir.
Thank you, Mollie. Arthur, I'd like you to meet Mister McCrimmon.
May I ask what you are doing in this house?
I was just about to ask you the same thing.
Oh, you gentlemen have been introduced?
Aye, we've met.
It seems, Ruth, your father has the oddest collection of house guests these days.
Now, Arthur, please. You must forgive him, Mister McCrimmon.
Ah, it's becoming a habit.
I don't care for insolence.
Well, I'm not keen on arrogance myself.
Why, you bite at each other as if you were old enemies.
I'm sorry if I seem rude.
Come, I want you to be friends. Won't you be so, to please me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall has another painful attack.

Dialogue.Line: Arthur? Arthur, what is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall runs from the room.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me. Arthur! What's the matter?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ruth follows Terrall. Shortly afterwards, Mollie enters.

Dialogue.Line: Sir?
Yes? Oh, I wish you'd call me Jamie.
Oh, I couldn't do that, sir. What would the master say?
Oh, who cares? What can I do for you?
If you'd tell me where your bags are, sir, yours and the Doctor, I'll have them taken up to your room.
Aye. Well, Mollie
Listen to me. Have them taken. I daresay I'll be doing it meself!
You see, we didn't have time to pick up the luggage. It'll be following.
Oh.
Why do you say you'll be doing it yourself?
Well, they do say, sir, that the house is haunted. Mister Kitson, the butler, left, and cook and the two footmen are complaining again.
Haunted?
Mmm. But, I've never heard anything, sir. I sleep like a log and always have.
Aye. Well, I'm glad you've got over the fright you had.
Oh, yes, that horrible man. Miss Ruth said it was all a game, but I don't know, sir. I've never fainted before, sir. Truly I haven't.
Not sir, Jamie. Tell me about Arthur Terrall.
Miss Ruth's fiancé, sir?
Aye.
Oh. Oh, he's a kind man, sir. Usually.
Usually?
Mmm. Well, when he's a bit odd or his temper's up, as it has been lately, I says to myself, Inkerman, and then it's all right.
Inkerman?
Yes sir. He was out in the Crimea, he was. They do say Mister Terrall was wounded out there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters quietly.

Dialogue.Line: Do you know, my uncle was killed at Inkerman, sir. So, you see, I do know what it's like with soldiers. Oh! oh, I'm sorry, sir.
It's all right, Mollie.
I didn't mean to.
Never mind.
Well, cook said to me that if I did some dusting it would be all right.
That'll do. Yes, Mollie, thank you very much. It's all right.
You won't tell the master, will you?
I wouldn't dream of telling him.
Thank you, sir. Sorry.
Thank you very much. Bye bye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mollie leaves.

Dialogue.Line: You'll have to brush up on your history. I can't be around to cover up for you all the time. Now then, in the Crimean War, the English, the French and the Turks fought the Russians.
Oh, forget about all that!
Oh, I thought you'd be interested. I watched the Charge of the Light Brigade. Magnificent folly.
Look, where've you been?
Oh, just looking around.
Aye. What for, the Tardis?
Jamie, you're in a temper!
Oh, am I? Is that bad, then? Does that mean I won't be co-operative. I won't do everything I'm told?
What was that?
I overheard you and Waterfield.
You were eavesdropping.
Well, whatever it is, I don't like what you're doing.
Now, you listen to me, Jamie!
No, Doctor. You're forgetting the Tardis was stolen and a man was murdered. Now, how am I supposed to tell when I see you as friendly as you like with the murderer.
Waterfield did not murder that man!
All right, then. But he stole the Tardis and that still makes him a thief.
The Daleks forced him to!
The Daleks! You keep telling me about the Daleks, and I haven't even seen one. You're always on about them, but where are they?
Now, you listen to me.
No, you'll not get round me this time, Doctor. You're up to something with Waterfield and Maxtible. Now what is it? Some scientific invention? Ah, here's your friend.
Just a little argument.
I heard voices raised.
That's not all you'll hear!
Jamie seems to think that I'm lying to him.
Well, aren't you?
He doesn't believe the Daleks are here.
It's the truth.
Aye, the truth you told Arthur Terrall, maybe, that your daughter was in Paris.
I had to tell him that.
So you've got another story to tell me?
I tell you that the Daleks are holding my daughter prisoner in the south wing of this house, Mister McCrimmon.
Then why don't you try and get her back, ay? What are you doing?
Well, what can I do? Now, be fair, Jamie. Waterfield's tied hand and foot because of his daughter, and we're tied hand and foot because of the Tardis!
Aye, and that's all you can think about, isn't it? The Tardis. Well, you can all stand around doing nothing. I'm sick to death of it.
Now just where are you going?
To be by myself for a bit. Do you mind?
No, not a bit. But one word of warning. Don't you try to be a one-man army. You leave well alone. I won't have you ruining everything trying to rescue Victoria Waterfield. Now, you understand?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie pushes the Doctor out of his way and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Well, are you sure you didn't go a little too far, Doctor?
Adding a little fuel to the fire. Tell Maxtible that I'll be along to his laboratory shortly.
Oh, very well, Doctor, if you're sure.
Oh, yes, quite sure. Once our young friend has cooled his heels a bit, he'll launch off on his own. And you dropped the hint about the south wing beautifully.
Well, what is it? You wanted to see me.
Very good of you to talk to me, gov'nor.
Well, never mind all that. I'll give you two minutes, no more.
I want me rights. No more, no less.
What do you mean, rights?
Half a guinea, you gave me, and it ain't what we said.
You were lucky to get anything.
That ain't fair.
You'll get no more from me. I warn you, keep away from this house and this property. Find the nearest road to London and take it.
Oh, yeah, London, sir. Yeah. I daresay I could earn something for me stories there.
Stories?
Oh, I won't detain an important gentleman like yourself. Like as not me two minutes is up anyway.
What do you mean, stories?
It's all right, sir. I'll take a stroll to London.
Don't play with me.
Get off me. If you must know, there's plenty who'd pay to hear what I've got to tell them.
Indeed.
Yeah. You blows too hot and cold for me, telling me this one minute and that the next and not paying up.
You know nothing.
Don't I, though?
Who'd believe you anyway?
Pay me off, and there's the end of it.
Oh, blackmail is it? Get out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Toby starts to leave, but Terrall has one of his attacks, grabs a pitchfork and lunges at Toby. Toby manages to knock him out. He searches his pockets and finds gold coins and a set of keys.

Dialogue.Line: Maybe I don't know much to tell, but I'll wager I'll find something in the house that's worth me trouble. So I'll say thank you, Mister Terrall, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The moon shines down on the house. Mollie brings an oil lamp in.

Dialogue.Line: It's only me, Mollie.
It's over here, sir. I took it from the master's study.
It's marvellous. Thank you.
Here, is this what you wanted?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's a plan of the house.

Dialogue.Line: Perfect, yes. Let's see. This is the south wing here?
Yes sir, but it's been closed off.
Completely?
Oh no, sir. only because of some repairs about a twelve month back. But the door may be locked.
Can you show me?
All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie takes the map and lamp.

Dialogue.Line: What're you going to do, sir?
I'm off to hunt a few ghosties, Mollie.
Every single one of Jamie's reactions will be recorded on these Dalek machines.
And then transformed into thought patterns on silver wire. A wonderful creation. DALEK 1: It is for you, Doctor, to select the major feelings to make up this human factor.
Oh, yes. I quite understand.
We can rely on the Doctor to give us all cooperation.
We shall watch your every move.
I'm sure you will. And every step of Jamie's progress will be covered?
Yes. DALEK 2: The young human being is on his way.
Then the recording machines can be set in action.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mollie leads Jamie to the hidden doorway.

Dialogue.Line: Here?
Yes, sir. I once remember the master stepping away from here. When he saw me, he was very cross and told me to keep away.
I see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie searches the alcove.

Toby has got into the house using Terrall's keys and is searching the place for loot. He looks into a packing case then is aware of movement on the other side of the room. A Dalek glides towards him. Toby tries to run and gets killed, screaming as he dies.
The scream is heard through the house.

Dialogue.Line: What was that? What was that?
That was no ghost, Mollie, that's for sure. That was a human voice.
Oh, sir.
Look, Mollie, take the candle and go back to your room. Will you do that?
Yes, sir.
Now, do you want me to see you safely there?
No, no. I'll be all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mollie leaves. Jamie finds the candle and matches on the shelf and lights it. He finds greasy fingerprints on the doorframe and the hidden switches. The door opens. As Jamie moves forward, hot wax drips onto his fingers and he stops to wipe it off just as the metal spikes thud down in front of him. Jamie ducks under the spikes into the next corridor.

Kemel steps forward, arms outstretched. Jamie ducks underneath them. Kemel grabs Jamie's fist and squeezes it. Jamie shoulders Kemel's stomach and the wrestler staggers back releasing his hand. They circle each other until Jamie elbows Kemel in the stomach again with no effect. Kemel gets a glancing blow on Jamie, knocking him down. Then Kemel kicks out and Jamie grabs his foot, making him fall backwards onto a chair which breaks. Next, Kemel gets Jamie in a headlock but Jamie gets his foot behind Kemel's knee and overbalances them both. They exchange kicks and blows until Kemel hits his head against the wall. Jamie goes into the nearest room and shuts the door.

It is full of dusty furniture and packing cases. Kemel rushes in. Jamie dodges at the last moment and Kemel goes out through an open window. Jamie looks out to see Kemel sliding down a small roof until he is just hanging on to the gutter two stories above the ground. Jamie throws down a rope and braces himself as the wrestler climbs back up to safety. Meanwhile, A Dalek takes an embroidered lace handkerchief into Victoria's old room and puts it on the floor. Kemel climbs back through the window and shakes his head. Jamie goes back to the corridor and Kemel does not follow.

Jamie passes an open doorway and sees the handkerchief on the floor. He looks around and goes to pick it up. Suddenly Kemel knocks him over onto the bed. An axe swings out of the wall and slices through the air where Jamie had been standing. The pair continue the search together. A Dalek watches them go.

Dialogue.Line: It took courage to fight Maxtible's Turkish wrestler.
The Daleks are afraid of nothing and no-one.
But Jamie saved the Turk's life.
Human weakness.
If he hadn't, he would have died in that room of yours. If you want the human factor, a part of it must include mercy.
What is he doing here?
(A common thief, come to see what he could steal. No mystery here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Dalek comes out of the mirror room.

Dialogue.Line: The intruder was destroyed.
Well, what are we to do? Where is the Doctor? He must be told.
No.
Why not?
Obey me!
Waterfield, I beg of you, do not antagonise the, er, our friends.
Oh, why do you consistently avoid reality, Maxtible? Another man has died. Can't you grasp that fact?
You will hide the remains of the dead human intruder.
No!
That is an order!
We must do as they say, Waterfield. We cannot anger them. Here. Here, wrap the body in this.
No.
We must. Have you lost your mind? Don't you want to see your daughter again?
There's no end to this. The hands of the Devil.
Dispose of the body. Obey!
Waterfield, what is the matter with you? We are not to blame for everything that has happened. No English judge or jury would find it in their hearts to convict us of one solitary thing.
It'll never come to that.
And what may that remark mean?
I have one purpose only, to see my daughter out of the hands of those foul monsters. When that is achieved, I shall confess my part in all that has happened.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Waterfield finishes wrapping Toby's corpse in a sheet, Maxtible opens a drawer in his workbench and removes a small pistol which he slips into his coat. Waterfield struggles to drag the body to the door.

Dialogue.Line: You must help me.
I am at your heels, my dear sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel helps Jamie to a window for some fresh air.

Dialogue.Line: That's better, thank you. Aye, you're an odd one. I'll say that. Aye, well, I suppose we're both a bit touched, eh? Knocking each other about the place and saving one another's lives. You don't say much, do you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel touches his lips and shakes his head.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I see. You can't talk. Aye. Well, you're a sight better than a number of people I know who can. I wonder what your name is?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Turk writes his name in the dust.

Dialogue.Line: Kemel? Well, I'm Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel bows over Jamie's hand.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, what is that? Now, come on now. I want none of that. We're to be friends, d'you hear? Friends.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel sees the handkerchief Jamie is holding.

Dialogue.Line: Aye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel points to the initials on it.

Dialogue.Line: V.W. I know. Victoria Waterfield.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel pulls a piece of folded paper from his belt. It contains a pressed flower.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Miss Waterfield gave you the flower? You like her? Of course. Then what are we fighting for? Do you not know what I'm doing here, Kemel? Victoria Waterfield is being held a prisoner here somewhere. Together? Aye, we'll go together. There's no one I'd rather have with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor adjusts the recording machine.
Waterfield and Maxtible carry in Toby's body and put it in a stall.

Dialogue.Line: What was that? Did you hear it?
Control your nerves.
But there was a noise.
Waterfield, go back to the house.
No, we have a task to perform.
Waterfield, I am sick to death of you.
What?
I take you into my house, you and your daughter, provide for you.
Yes, I know everything that you've done.
Small thanks do I get for it. I did not bring these terrible creatures here deliberately, you know that. Am I to blame for everything?
No, no.
It is your daughter they have kidnapped. One moment you beg me to do everything I can to rescue her, next moment you blame me.
Yes, I don't mean it like that. It's the price. First Kennedy, now this fellow. How many people must die so that my daughter can live?
We are not the murderers.
No, just the silent partners. But we're equally to blame because we stand by and do nothing.
Go back to the house, Waterfield. I understand you are under a stress. You try and get some sleep.
Sleep? I've not had one good night's rest since this started.
Well, you go back to your room. Near the end now. You have done enough.(Waterfield leaves. Maxtible aims his pistol at his back. Terrall steps out of the shadows and knocks the gun away.)
What are you doing?
Waterfield does not die yet.
He says he will confess everything.
Go back to the laboratory. I will dispose of the body. You will obey. You will obey!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Kemel hide in an alcove as a Dalek goes past.

Dialogue.Line: Wait. Never mind about those, Kemel, unless they catch sight of us. We seem to be going in the right direction.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They follow the Dalek at a distance, but they are being monitored in the Dalek laboratory. Jamie touches a small button in the wall at waist height and an alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: Down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A spotlight glares down and a huge ball on a pendulum swings between them, just missing their heads as they lie on the floor. Jamie and Kemel continue along the corridor very carefully.
The Doctor makes more adjustments.

Dialogue.Line: We do not trust you. What thoughts are you using now?
Human beings have five senses. Sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch. But there is instinct, too. Jamie used instinct to avoid your trap.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The corridor ends in a large hall with an open fireplace, and a minstrel's gallery at the far end. As Jamie watches, two Daleks enter and look up at the gallery. A door opens and Victoria steps out.

Dialogue.Line: Name?
Victoria.
Louder.
Victoria! Victoria Waterfield! You know my name!
Silence. Inspection is over. Return to your room.
She's very beautiful, Kemel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel smiles and takes a mace from the wall.

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do with that? You'll attack the Daleks, draw them off down the corridor, while I go up there and rescue her somehow? It's too dangerous, Kemel. Besides, it needs two of us up there. Oh, but how?
What is the significance of this thought pattern?

Suicidal attacks to gain an objective. Postulate. Self-preservation is a strong human factor. Jamie and his new friend are determined to succeed, but finding the girl is only part. Getting her away is another.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall drags Mollie inside.

Dialogue.Line: You'll come in here, Mollie, and explain yourself.
Oh, sir, please, sir, You're hurting me!
Now, what is this hysterical nonsense?
But, sir, I heard Miss Victoria's voice.
Did she say how the weather was in Paris? That's where she is, Mollie.
Well, I know that, sir, but I heard her speaking.
Where?
I was walking past the big fireplace in the hall, sir, and her voice sort of floated out of it.
Will you explain how you could possibly hear Miss Waterfield's voice when she's in Paris?
I know it can't be, sir, but I heard her as plain as anything.
Anyway, what were you doing in the hall?
Oh, well. I wasn't doing anything wrong, sir.
What were you doing in this part of the house at this hour?
Oh, I don't know.
You do know, and you'll tell me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ruth is in the doorway.

Dialogue.Line: Arthur!
I found this child creeping about the corridors.
I haven't done anything.
Be quiet!
Yes, sir.
She is miles from her room. Should have been in bed an hour since.
Did you have extra work, Mollie?
Yes, Miss Ruth. I did.
You're a liar!
Well, I haven't done anything, Miss. I haven't took nothing.
Arthur, the poor child's frightened out of her senses.
It's nothing but play acting. She's a mean, snivelling little minx.
But I haven't done anything, miss.
Go to the sitting room and wait there. Mister Maxtible will decide what to do with you.
But sir, I
Do as you are told!
Mollie, it's all right. Everything will be all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mollie leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Arthur, tell me what's wrong.
Wrong? Why should something be wrong?
Has my father influenced you in some way?
No, not your father.
Come away with me, please. I somehow feel if we delay, it'll be too late.
I can't go. Not yet.

I have done everything you have asked me to. You wanted an agency here on Earth to plan and prepare things for you. I have been that agency. Will you please tell those who give you orders that I am getting tired of waiting.
Do you threaten the Daleks?
Oh, surely threatening is not necessary. We have a partnership, an understanding.
You have obeyed us.

You have a strange way of putting things. I prefer to say that you have asked for certain services, I have provided those services punctually and efficiently. Now you really must look to your side of the bargain. It is not beyond me to ruin the entire enterprise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek knocks Maxtible down.

Dialogue.Line: Do not threaten! Obey!
Yes. Very well, I understand.
Obey the Daleks.
No, please. Please wait! The secret. The secret. You promised to give it to me. That is why I have done all this.
The Daleks know many secrets. You will learn the most important.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek goes into the mirrored room.

Dialogue.Line: I must not be frightened of them. It's just their way. They're different people. Alien. But they will tell me. Of course they will!
Father?
Ruth, I told you not to come in here.
I had to.
Under any circumstances.
Father, I simply had to. I heard you speaking to someone and there's no- one here. And Arthur is involved in some way.
Ah, Arthur. Yes.
Why has he become so changed? And Victoria Waterfield. Where is she?
My child, these are questions that I cannot answer. But, my dear, I will tell you one thing. One thing only, and then perhaps you may understand why there are secrets to be kept. You see this?
What is it?
A piece of ordinary metal. Of very little value, would you not say so?
I suppose so.

What does it weigh? A few pounds? Five, six, shall we say? For centuries now, men have searched for the greatest secret of all. Some say it was known to the ancient alchemists, some say that the secret never existed at all, but still the stories and the rumours, and the search goes on.
What secret?

The transmutation of metal into gold. Changing metal into gold. Now, perhaps, do you begin to understand a little? To possess such a secret would mean power and influence beyond all imagination. And I am about to discover this secret. Nothing will stop me. Nothing! Nobody!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria comes out onto the gallery again.

Dialogue.Line: Name?
Victoria.
Louder!
Victoria Waterfield! Victoria Waterfield!
Inspection is over. Return to your room.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria leaves. Jamie and Kemel hold the rope between them and move forward. Kemel throws the mace into the far corner to distract the Dalek, then they run forward, using the rope to catapult it into the blazing fireplace.

Dialogue.Line: Well, that's fixed that one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Kemel loop the rope over the railing of the gallery. Kemel holds the ends as Jamie climbs up.
Jamie and Kemel lasso the Dalek with the rope and catapult it through the broken railing. It crashes on the floor below and explodes.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, before we see any more of those mechanical beasties.
Kemel, my dear friend.
Aye, he's a good friend, right enough, Miss Waterfield.
And you?

Introductions in a moment, if you please. First, I'd like to make us a little bit more secure. Kemel, if we lash this bedstead across the door, it might just hold. Rope! That's it. We could do with a chest against it, I'm thinking. Another one on top, ay? Well now, they can't get in and we can't get out. So, where does that put us? Oh. Jamie McCrimmon. I, er, I came to give you this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie hands over the handkerchief.
The Doctor pours himself a glass of wine.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure you won't join me?
No, I won't. I very rarely touch it.
Oh, dear. Well, something else, perhaps?
No. Thank you.
I know. Let me ring for some food. Now, do join me?
No! You seem determined to involve me.
Yes, I do, don't I?
This is a large house. I prefer my own company.
Oh, how very unsociable.
Yes, possibly. No doubt you will enjoy your libation in one of the other rooms.
Liba? Oh. No, thank you. I'm perfectly happy here, thank you. I'm perfectly happy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor inspects the glass cases around the walls.

Dialogue.Line: What an extraordinary collection, isn't it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall takes a sword from the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I'm so sorry. You didn't, you weren't in the mood for talking, were you?
Shouldn't you be helping Waterfield and Maxtible with their experiment?
Yes, but I thought I'd have a little rest. I wanted to talk to you.
About what, pray?
About you, Mister Terrall. You interest me. Do you know something? Ever since I came to this house, I, why, this is Circassian, surely.
Do I know what?
Circassian. Ever since I came to this house, I have never seen you eat or drink anything. Now, that's curious, isn't it?
I dine alone.
Yes, I'd thought of that. But Waterfield has never seen you eat or drink either.
You seem to be a devotee of Edgar Allan Poe.
Oh, do I?
However it isn't wise to make assumptions.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall gestures at the Doctor with the sword.

Dialogue.Line: Nor to meddle in affairs which are none of your business.
Touché. Oh, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall rests the sword on a sideboard as the Doctor holds out his metal cup towards it.

Dialogue.Line: A perfectly ordinary sword, and yet it appears to be magnetic. And see. Directly you let go it loses its magnetism. Now, if I didn't know better, Mister Terrall, I'd say that you were full of some sort of electricity.
Doctor? Excuse me. You're wanted.
Oh, thank you. Excuse me.
Doctor. No doubt you're a keen student of human nature, but some things are better left alone.
No, Mister Terrall, I am not a student of human nature. I am a professor of a far wider academy, of which human nature is merely a part. All forms of life interest me.
I'm sorry to interrupt you Doctor, but it's something rather urgent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor follows Waterfield from the room. Terrall pours himself a glass of wine, but before he can take a sip, he has another of his attacks.

Dialogue.Line: Obey, obey, obey!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall falls to his knees, clutching his head in agony.

Dialogue.Line: And so the Doctor and I were brought to the house.
Why did you risk your life to try and rescue me?
Would you like some more water?
You are too modest. It was a silly question.
Tell me, how did they come to capture you in the first place?
I don't remember. And yet, I seem to remember in the back of my mind, somebody, oh, I can't recall who it was, telling me to walk. And I obeyed, blindly and without interest.
Aye. You were drugged, maybe?
I simply don't know. The only thing I remember is waking up in a bare room with one of those terrible, terrible things.
Well, what do you remember before that, apart from this hazy recollection?
I was reading in the sitting room, but I couldn't concentrate because I was so worried about Papa. I think I fell asleep over my book.
You see, how you came under the power of the Daleks is very important. They can't have done as much as they have without some help.
Help? From somebody in the house?
Yes, from someone who wants their plans to succeed. Someone who drugged you or found a way of putting you under the power of the Daleks.
But how? How could it be done without my knowing?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible is sitting in a wing chair, with Mollie standing in front of him staring vacantly ahead. Terrall is watching from across the room as Maxtible swings a jewelled fob watch in front of Mollie.

Dialogue.Line: You are paying attention, Mollie?
Yes, sir.
Then keep your eyes fixed on the jewel. See how the light catches it? Every facet sparkles, does it not?
Yes, sir.
Flashing, flashing, like a collection of sparks. But I know you are tired, Mollie. You are tired, are you not? Tell me.
I am tired.
Then close your eyes and sleep. You need have no fear, my child. A deep, heavy sleep. Oh, you are so exhausted. And now, in your sleep, you will hear only my voice.
Only your voice.

You have been dreaming, Mollie. Dreaming that there are mysteries in this house, that all is not well. You have dreamt that you heard the voice of Miss Waterfield. But it was all your imagination. It was nothing but a dream. Do you understand?
Nothing but a dream.

That is correct. Now, when I tell you to open your eyes, you will go back to your room and lie down on your bed. And when you awaken, the dream will fade and you will forget all your suspicions, for they might be injurious to your health. Now, open your eyes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mollie leaves.

Dialogue.Line: An excellent subject. I'd no idea that mesmerism was one of your accomplishments.
How else do you suppose that I persuaded Victoria to go to the Daleks?
I see. What of the experiment?
It progresses.
Are you sure of the Doctor?
No, but he is watched.
And Waterfield?
Waterfield's usefulness is nearing it's end. Your intervention in the stables was untimely.
Maxtible, help me!
What do you mean?
I seem to be in the grip of something. Sometimes my thoughts are clear, sometimes muddled. I don't know what's happened. Help me.
I can only help you if you obey me.
But I obey our masters.
I prefer to call them our colleagues. It is their wish that you should obey me.
You? But you would have killed Waterfield if they hadn't made me stop you.
A slight misunderstanding on the part of our friends. But now it is your turn to obey. I have a task for you to perform.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible touches a hidden switch and a panel opens in the wall, revealing a secret passageway.

Dialogue.Line: This entrance leads to the south wing of my house and to a certain room. You will fetch Victoria Waterfield and bring her to me.
But, Maxtible.
Do as you are told!
Obey! Obey! Obey!
Well?
I will bring Victoria to you.
Is it finished?
Very nearly. Jamie was magnificent. But then I knew he would be. He produced a whole battery of emotions, each one of which is imprinted in here, see?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up one of three glass capsules full of fine wiring.

Dialogue.Line: The human factor?
Well, a part of it at least. The better part. Courage, pity, chivalry, friendship, even compassion. Some of the virtues.
In there?
Yes, it's a positronic brain. We're going to implant one of these into each of these three Daleks here. The dormant ones.
So the end is in sight?
Perhaps.
What happens when the capsule comes into contact with the brain of the Dalek and starts to influence it?
Perhaps it'll drive them insane.
Or turn them into super-beings?
Well, that is their purpose. At least, I imagine it is. I can't help feeling that there's more in this than meets the eye.
You have completed the experiment?
Yes, the three capsules are nearly ready.
Stand in front of the cabinet and speak when you have finished.
Yes, yes. I understand.
Doctor, be careful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek goes back into the mirrored room.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Hmm?
You can't. You mustn't do it.
What do you mean?
You must stop the experiment.
Oh, you should have thought of that some time ago.
I know.
It's no use having a conscience now.
But before it's too late.
It was too late when they took away your daughter. It was too late when you stole my Tardis and lured me to this house and this century.
Yes, but what are we doing? What are we really doing? Turning these creatures into super-beings.
Homo superiense.
Adding all that is best and finest in human nature to all that is brilliant and superior in them. They'll be unbeatable.
That is their purpose.
But you're making over the whole world to them. Don't you realise that? Our world, our future. They will enslave us for all time.
That, Mister Waterfield, remains to be seen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns back to his work. Waterfield sees the metal bar that Kemel bent and picks it up. The Doctor grabs his arm before he can strike.

Dialogue.Line: Attacking me will do no good. Now listen. You've done all of this because of your daughter. Jamie is with her now and they're both still in the power of the Daleks. They must be set free!
And sacrifice a whole world. A history, past, present and future? Destroy an entire race?
Yes. I don't think you quite realise what you're saying. But yes, it may come to that. It may very well come to that.
So, with the Dalek's eye stick pointing forward, Kemel and I were able to tiptoe up behind him, throw the rope over his head and throw him into the fire.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kemel gestures at the packing cases barricading the door. Liquid is coming in underneath them.

Dialogue.Line: What are they doing?
They must be trying to get through. You'd better stand back, Miss Waterfield.
Why not break the door down? They're strong enough.

I don't know. Maybe they want us alive. I just don't know. Is it hot? Aye, well, there's no smoke. It could be one of their newfangled inventions trying to melt their way through. Look, you'd better stand right back. Why didn't they try before this, is what I don't understand. Anyway, we'll make it as hard for them as we possibly can. Come on, Kemel. Excuse me. Take this. That's it. That one too.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The men pile more boxes around the door. A panel in the wall slides open behind Victoria and Terrall enters.

Dialogue.Line: What's puzzling me is, there were two on the way up here, and there was a Dalek up here. And you were up

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall pulls Victoria into the secret passage and the door closes.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, Miss Waterfield!
Jamie!
Hey, did you hear it? Of course! Why didn't I use my head? There's another way in and out of here. Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie searches for the opening switch as the barricade begins to crumble. They open the panel and escape just before the Daleks break in.
At the trophy room door, Victoria frees herself while Terrall tries to open it. Meanwhile, further back along the passage.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, no. Two ways to go. Kemel, you go that way. If it's a dead end, follow me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall hears someone approaching, and goes into the trophy room. Jamie sees a slip of light coming from under the door. He searches for the switch.

Jamie pauses to get used to the bright light again. Terrall attacks him with a sword, and misses. Jamie dodges his blade and gets his own sword from the far wall. They fence, and are evenly matched. Jamie finally corners Terrall.

Dialogue.Line: Right. Where's Victoria Waterfield?
You'll never find her.
Tell me! TERRALL Never!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie continues the fight. Ruth and Mollie appear in the doorway.

Dialogue.Line: Mollie, go and fetch the Doctor. Quick, hurry!
Yes, mistress.
Arthur! Stop it. I implore you. Stop it.
Leave me!
Please, I implore you. Stop it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall suddenly drops his sword and falls to his knees, clutching his head in agony.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, what have you done?
But I can't understand it. He just collapsed.
Arthur, are you all right? What's happened to him?
Do you want to save this man's life?
What do you mean?
Do you?
Yes!
Then take him away from here. As far away as possible. Go and get the carriage round to the stables. You go too, Mollie. We'll bring him out you. Now go along.
But, Doctor Oh, Mollie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor finds a slim black box inside Terrall's jacket.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I thought he was under some sort of control. Come along.
The creatures.
Yes, don't worry about them.
There's danger, I tell you. Some kind of danger.
Yes, I know there's danger. You must leave here immediately.
The house, the creatures abroad.
Now you leave them to us. Take Ruth Maxtible with you. She's waiting for you at the stables.
Yes, very well.
Can you manage?
Yes, I think so. Wait. There's something at the back of my mind. Victoria Waterfield. I feel I've harmed her in some way.
Victoria is safe and well.
You You're positive?
I'm positive. Now we'll take care of her. You must leave immediately.
Yes, if that's what you want. I'll find Ruth by the stables?
Yes!
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Terrall leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Well, that's fine for Ruth Maxtible, but you lied about Victoria.
Yes, Jamie, and we must turn that lie into a truth.
We've done it! Maxtible, they've got the human factor. We've done it! What are they doing now? Look, they're all joining in. They're playing train!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor blows on his recorder.

Dialogue.Line: Trains, trains, trains, trains.
Oh! Oh, now what is it? Oh, we're on a roundabout. They're playing roundabout. Oh, I'm getting dizzy. Oh, dear. Oh, I'm dizzy! Oh, I'm dizzy.
Diz-zy, diz-zy, dizzy, Doctor.
Maxtible, do you hear that? They've got a sense of humour.
I'm glad you are so easily amused.
Yes.
Well, I congratulate you, Doctor. They are almost human.
They are.
And I will now leave you to your little games.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maxtible leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, thank you.
Well, how old are they now, Doctor, mentally?
Oh, they're just young children, but they'll grow up very fast. Within a matter of hours. Now, come here, all of you. Come along, gather round. Come here. Now then, come along, come along.
Who is this?
Oh, this is Jamie. He's a friend.
Friend. Hello, friend.
Well say hello, Jamie.
Hello.
You know what a friend is, don't you? It's somebody who likes you, who wants to help you and share with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has been scratching a greek letter on the base of each Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: There we are.
What have you done?
I have given you all names. Alpha, Beta and Omega.
Alpha.
Yes.
Beta.
Yes.
Omega.
Yes.
Alpha.
Beta.
Omega.
Alpha.
Beta.
Omega.
Yes, yes, yes. Now, this is Jamie and I am Doctor. We are friends.
Friends, friends.
Jamie, Doctor.
Friends, friends.
We must go now. We are called.
Go? Called? Go where? What do you mean, go?
All Daleks are ordered to return to Skaro.
Return to Skaro? But that's the Dalek plan.
Friend.
But if the Daleks are returning to Skaro, where's Victoria?
Victoria! We left her in the secret passage. Come along, follow me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jamie run up the spiral staircase. Maxtible and Waterfield enter.

Dialogue.Line: I assure you, my dear Waterfield, Victoria is perfectly safe.
But where is she?
The Daleks have released her.
Released her?
Yes, yes, yes, yes.
